Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
INVOCATION - Delivered by: Reverend Patrick J. Keating, Deputy CEO of Catholic Charities Brooklyn and Queens, CEO of Catholic Migration Services, located at 310 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, NY  11215.

Motion to spread the Invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Brannan.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by Reverend Patrick J. Keating, Deputy CEO of Catholic Charities Brooklyn and Queens, CEO of Catholic Migration Services, located at 310 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11215.

Council Member Brannan moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Coupled on General Orders Calendar
Resolution calling on New York City health care institutions to contract with industrial laundry companies that respect workers’ legal rights and adhere to area standards for wages and benefits.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: New York City health care institutions to contract with industrial laundry companies that respect workers’ legal rights and adhere to area standards for wages and benefits.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.2583, which would establish a noise tax on non-essential helicopter and seaplane flights in cities with a population of one million or more.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 5 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item: 
Council Member Felder.

.Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Approved, by Council
Items.MatterName: Establish a noise tax on non-essential helicopter and seaplane flights in cities with a population of one million or more (A.2583).

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to regulating helicopter operations at city owned heliports to reduce noise
Items.MatterName: Regulating helicopter operations at city owned heliports to reduce noise.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Federal Aviation Administration to ban all non-essential helicopter travel, including tourist and chartered helicopter flights over New York City.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 3 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Marmorato, Paladino, and Vernikov.

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: United States Federal Aviation Administration to ban all non-essential helicopter travel, including tourist and chartered helicopter flights over NYC.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.6311 and S.7381, which would prohibit certain non-essential flight operations at municipal heliports and Hudson River Park.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 5 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Prohibit certain non-essential flight operations at municipal heliports and Hudson River Park (A.6311/S.7381).

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Governor to sign S.929/A.2141, which, having been passed by both the New York State Senate and the New York State Assembly, would extend protections over personal health information.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 5 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item: 
Council Member Felder.

.Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Extend protections over personal health information (S.929/A.2141).

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Department of Health to implement regulations requiring hospitals in New York City to adhere to the World Professional Association for Transgender Health’s Standards of Care 8, to ensure medical professionals can provide high-quality and ethical treatment for individuals with gender dysphoria.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 6 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, Zhuang, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item: 
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Dept of Health to implement regulations requiring hospitals in NYC to adhere to the World Professional Association for Transgender Health’s Standards of Care 8.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to introduce and pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation to prohibit out-of-state access to the New York State Prescription Monitoring Program’s data for certain medications including abortion medications, hormone therapy, and puberty blockers.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 5 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be City Charter Rule Adopted approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Prohibit out-of-state access to the New York State Prescription Monitoring Program’s data for certain medications including abortion medications, hormone therapy, and puberty blockers.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, S.1633/A.2613, which would provide additional protections for the sensitive health information of patients, including information related to abortion or gender affirming care, and require all health information networks, electronic health record systems, and health care providers to provide patients with a right to restrict the disclosures of such patient’s health information
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 5 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote in the negative against this item:  
Council Members Holden, Marmorato, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Ariola).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:
Council Member Felder.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Provide additional protections for the sensitive health information of patients (S.1633/A.2613)

Items.Title:
Introduction & Reading of Bills
See Attached
Discussion of Resolutions
Resolutions
General Discussion
Extension of Remarks

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

Pursuant to Section 33-a of the New York City Charter, the New York City Council may vote on the following items no earlier than 30 days from the date of this notice. The New York City Council reserves the right to vote without the notice required pursuant to Section 33-a on any proposed local laws that do not relate to the public safety operations of the New York City Police Department, the Fire Department or the Department of Correction.
Items.AgendaNote: INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS - Pursuant to Section 33-a of the New York City Charter, the New York City Council may vote on the following items no earlier than 30 days from the date of this notice. The New York City Council reserves the right to vote without the notice required pursuant to Section 33-a on any proposed local laws that do not relate to the public safety operations of the New York City Police Department, the Fire Department or the Department of Correction.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to a study and report on the provision of agency services to older adults with certain neurological and mental health conditions
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Study and report on the provision of agency services to older adults with certain neurological and mental health conditions.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the correction of sex designations on death records
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MatterName: Correction of sex designations on death records.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress to pass, and the President to sign, legislation that would expand Medicare to include long-term services and supports for seniors and individuals with disabilities
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Expand Medicare to include long-term services and supports for seniors and individuals with disabilities.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation prohibiting the issuance of police courtesy cards
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting the issuance of police courtesy cards.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress and the President to take steps to protect social security.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Calling on the United States Congress and the President to take steps to protect social security.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring basic training in behavioral support strategies for certain staff at juvenile detention facilities
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Children and Youth
Items.MatterName: Requiring basic training in behavioral support strategies for certain staff at juvenile detention facilities.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of legal assistance on compliance with accessibility laws for small business tenants
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Small Business
Items.MatterName: Provision of legal assistance on compliance with accessibility laws for small business tenants.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the police commissioner providing district attorneys with access to electronic materials for discovery purposes
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Police commissioner providing district attorneys with access to electronic materials for discovery purposes.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to correcting excess pay differentials for paraprofessionals arising from pattern bargaining practices
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Correcting excess pay differentials for paraprofessionals arising from pattern bargaining practices.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to communications in adjudicative proceedings by certain public servants
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered Governmental Operations, State & Federal Legislation
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations, State & Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Communications in adjudicative proceedings by certain public servants.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Liu, S.7121-A, and Assembly Member Hooks, A.6781-B, “AN ACT authorizing the discontinuance of certain parkland in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in the borough of Queens”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations, State & Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Discontinuance of certain parkland in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in the borough of Queens (S. 7121-A/A. 6781-B).

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the New York State Governor to sign, S.4045/A.2299, requiring the installation of intelligent speed assistance devices for repeated violation of maximum speed limits.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Requiring the installation of intelligent speed assistance devices for repeated violation of maximum speed limits. ( S.4045/A.2299)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation to amend the vehicle and traffic law to permit a motor vehicle’s Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) to be listed in a “Notice of Violation,” instead of license plate number,  in circumstances when a license plate of such vehicle is missing, concealed, obscured, or distorted.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Amend the vehicle and traffic law to permit a motor vehicle’s Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) to be listed in a “Notice of Violation,” instead of license plate number.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of housing preservation and development to create an in-person housing portal assistance program
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of housing preservation and development to create an in-person housing portal assistance program.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to notifications regarding applications in New York City’s housing portal and designation of a representative to receive notifications
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Notifications regarding applications in New York City’s housing portal and designation of a representative to receive notifications.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to how affordable housing units which subsequently became vacant are rented through the housing portal
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: How affordable housing units which subsequently became vacant are rented through the housing portal.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to requiring the commissioner of finance to study and make recommendations relating to the feasibility of implementing a lifetime income tax exemption
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Requiring the commissioner of finance to study and make recommendations relating to the feasibility of implementing a lifetime income tax exemption.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

Items.Title:
By The Chair of the Land Use Committee (Council Member Salamanca)
Pursuant to Sections 11.20(b-d) of the Council Rules and Section 197-d(b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Application Nos. C 250024 MMM and C 250099 ZSM (Western Rail Yard Modifications) shall be subject to Council review.  These items are related to Application Nos. M 250100 LDM and N 250098 ZRM.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, Western Rail Yard Modifications, Manhattan (C 250024 MMM, C 250099 ZSM, M 250100 LDM and N 250098 ZRM.)

Items.MinutesNote: The Majority Leader (Council Member Farías) presiding as the President Pro Tempore.

The presence of a quorum was announced by the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías).

There were 48 Council Members marked present at this Stated Meeting.

There is presently one vacant seat on the Council pending the swearing-in of the certified winner of the Special Elections of  April 29, 2025 (51st CD, Staten Island).

The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following 47-0-1 vote:

Items.MinutesNote: At this point the Speaker (Council Member Adams) made the following announcements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Adams), the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) adjourned these proceedings to meet again for the Stated Meeting of Thursday, May 1, 2025.

MICHAEL McSWEENEY, City Clerk
Clerk of the Council

The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

At this point, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Farías) declared that the aforementioned items were adopted and referred to the Committee on Land Use and to the appropriate Land Use Subcommittee.

Items.Title: Passed The Consent Agenda
